guide.introduction: The TurtleBot mobile robot is designed for both academic and hobbyist researchers. The open-source hardware design provides excellent documentation for adding modifications and extending the capabilities of the robot in hardware or software. The robot is available for purchase as a kit or, if your research budget is limited, this guide will help you extend your TurtleBot by adding an arm.
guide.introduction_rendered:
The TurtleBot mobile robot is designed for both academic and hobbyist researchers. The open-source hardware design provides excellent documentation for adding modifications and extending the capabilities of the robot in hardware or software. The robot is available for purchase as a kit or, if your research budget is limited, this guide will help you extend your TurtleBot by adding an arm.

Relevant parts
  • TurtleBot Arm Assembly
  • ArbotiX Robocontroller
  • Project box
  • 6-32x5/8" BHCS
  • Bioloid 180mm 3 Pin Cable
  • FTDI Breakout Board
  • 1.5 feet of 20 gauge wire (2 colors)
Tools
  • Screwdriver, small, Phillips

lines.text: Attach the project box for the ArbotiX board to the top of the TurtleBot. Anywhere on the top plate will do.
lines.text_raw: Attach the project box for the ArbotiX board to the top of the TurtleBot. Anywhere on the top plate will do.

lines.text: Then place the Arbotix board inside with the FTDI breakout board and power cable attached.
lines.text_raw: Then place the Arbotix board inside with the FTDI breakout board and power cable attached.

lines.text: Use Bioloid 180mm 3-pin connectors to daisy-chain the servos together.
lines.text_raw: Use Bioloid 180mm 3-pin connectors to daisy-chain the servos together.

lines.text: Start with the gripper joint, and connect each successive joint to the previous one.
lines.text_raw: Start with the gripper joint, and connect each successive joint to the previous one.

lines.text: Finally, attach an extra connector to the base joint. This will attach to the Arbotix board.
lines.text_raw: Finally, attach an extra connector to the base joint. This will attach to the Arbotix board.

steps.title: Attach the TurtleBot Arm to Your TurtleBot

lines.text: Attach the arm base standoffs to the 4 holes highlighted in the picture using 4 6-32 x 3/4" screws on the bottom of the standoffs.
lines.text_raw: Attach the arm base standoffs to the 4 holes highlighted in the picture using 4 6-32 x 3/4" screws on the bottom of the standoffs.

lines.text: Make sure that the rounded protruding edge of the base is facing forward: that is, so that the arm gets the most reach over the edge of the robot.
lines.text_raw: Make sure that the rounded protruding edge of the base is facing forward: that is, so that the arm gets the most reach over the edge of the robot.

lines.text: Finally, attach the loose Dynamixel  cable to the Arbotix.
lines.text_raw: Finally, attach the loose Dynamixel  cable to the Arbotix.

lines.text: Disassemble the decks of the TurtleBot to have access to the iRobot Create and TurtleBot Power Board.
lines.text_raw: Disassemble the decks of the TurtleBot to have access to the iRobot Create and TurtleBot Power Board.

lines.text: Attach the power cable made in the TurtleBot Power Board cable tutorial to the TurtleBot Power Board in the base.
lines.text_raw: Attach the power cable made in the TurtleBot Power Board cable tutorial to the TurtleBot Power Board in the base.

lines.text: Attach the other side of the power cable to the screw terminals on the Arbotix.
lines.text_raw: Attach the other side of the power cable to the screw terminals on the Arbotix.

lines.text: Green is ground, and white is power in the images. We suggest you use a better coloring scheme in your build.
lines.text_raw: Green is ground, and white is power in the images. We suggest you use a better coloring scheme in your build.

lines.text: Follow the tutorials on http://www.ros.org/wiki/turtlebot_arm to set up the software.
lines.text_raw: Follow the tutorials on http://www.ros.org/wiki/turtlebot_arm to set up the software.
